content.description: How high can you get your feet?  Hopefully, high enough to solve this one.
content.location: Start approx 5 feet right of Popover, directly under next roof (second highest on wall).  Climb straight up through roof to the top.  There is an easier variation where you traverse right to escape the roof, then up to top; it goes around 5.6.

content.description: Classic Gunks: Hit a roof, layback a seam, long reach through crux.
content.location: Start right of Flapjack under a low, small roof with seam on right side of face over roof.  Go up to roof, traverse right to seam, follow seam up to left side of higher roof, climb slightly bulging face to top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: A seldom-done route due to regular seeping, but fun nonetheless.
content.protection: Pretty good gear, small finger sizes helpful.
content.location: On the first part of the Breakfast Wall you see, head approx 20 feet left of arete.  Start under pine tree at top, follow obvious broken corners and seam to top.

content.description:
Start either direct on the arete (harder start), or move onto the right side of the arete for an easier start.  Follow arete to top.  4th-class scramble to the top and walk-off. 

  Very easy beginner's route. A good intro to climbing, as you're not very far off the ground. The climbing isn't difficult, and the rock is slabby rather than vertical. 

  The dashed line is an alternate start; goes about 5.5, but it's only one move.
content.protection: Pro is PG, no bolts, no fixed gear, gear-only anchor (can sling a couple trees with long-enough static line).
content.location: This is the first route you see when you reach the Breakfast Wall - right on the first arete.

content.description: The crux is about 1/2-2/3 of the way up.  Very balancy face route with small holds.
content.protection: Small, barely adequate, definite ground-fall potential if you blow a move near the top.  Gear anchor only.  3rd-4th class scramble left from top of route to reach top of cliff.
content.location: Right-most route of the main Breakfast Wall area; the face of the left-facing flake that makes up Cornflake.  Go up middle of face, staying off the edge of the flake.

content.description: Wander upward to a short flaring vertical handcrack on the right and pocket on the left, continue straight up to the top.
content.protection: Gear anchor with long static line from the top, can be toproped without leading
content.location: Halfway between the arete on the right and the crack of Morning Cup on the left

content.description: Another seldom-done route, due to a tricky anchor and seepage.
content.location: Start approx 20 feet right of Easy Over, at tree growing out of second tier.  Go straight up left-facing corner to top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: Classic layback route with added handholds on the face for added security.  Must avoid the promiscuous tree along the way.  Crux is moving onto the flake edge from below.
content.protection: G-PG protection; G if you have larger gear (#4 cam), PG otherwise.
content.location: Climb the obvious left-facing flake on the right end of the Breakfast Wall.  3rd-4th class scramble to the left to reach the top of the cliff.  Gear-only anchor.

content.description: This one is not bad, until the crux move escaping the roof; the only holds are questionable, and don't feel secure.  *shrug*  It's what you've got.  Kind of a one- or two-move wonder, this route.
content.protection: Adequate, but make sure your belayer is attentive.
content.location: Start under highest roof on wall.  Climb up to right-facing flake under roof, escape left, go to top.

content.description: Shaded belay areas, shaded routes, gear-only anchors.  Good mix of route levels, from 5.3 to 5.7.  Watch out for copperheads at the top of the cliff area during the appropriate season.
